data.title: Show files in the FileSystem Tree View
data.body:
We are several developers at my company who have been working with both Unity, Cocos Creator and Godot. In Unity and Cocos Creator it's possible to view files in the hierarchy view but in the Godot engine this is not possible. In our opinion it makes it a lot easier to to work in a game editor when you can see all your files in the tree view. 

We are currently working on our third game in the Godot engine and we are still not comfortable using the FileSystem view in Godot. This indicates to us that the current way of showing the tree view might not be optimal, at least not for all developers.

**Idea for improvement: Make a toggle button for displaying files in the FileSystem view**    

This issue shows a mockup:
#4570

data.title: Various corrections in 2D math.
data.body:
This is the follow up for the 2D changes mentioned in PR #6865. It fixes various mistakes regarding the order of matrix indices, order of transformation operations, and usage of atan2 function.

Affected code in the Godot code base will be fixed in a later commit in this PR.

data.title: AnimationPlayer: Add animation name to "finished" signal
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot c798ff1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

The `finished` signal needs the current animation name as argument like `animation_started(String name)`.

Now:
```gdscript
func _on_AnimationPlayer_finished():
	if get_node("path/to/AnimationPlayer").get_current_animation() == 'explode':
		emit_signal('explode')
```

With animation name:
```gdscript
func _on_AnimationPlayer_finished(current_animation):
	if current_animation == 'explode':
		emit_signal('explode')
```

data.title: White screen until you resize
data.body:
Experienced on Mac OS X but @reduz  mentioned this was also witnessed on Windows.

The project picker opens up fine but when Godot opens itself the screen is blank until you resize it.
I suspect the issue is related to the window opening maximised and the code missing to initialise the screen size variables.

Will investigate further, just raising this to make sure it's not forgotten as  don't have time to look into this right this minute:)

data.title: ResourceLoader.has() uses localized paths, but Resource.set_path()/take_over_path() don't.
data.body:
On commit 0f7af4ea51744cda23c4d3c7481f9c332973d1d4 this is still true.
When setting the path for a resource, the path does not get localized, making future calls to has() return false unless the path is localized before setting.
Is this correct behaviour?

data.title: !create_func is true error on osx
data.body:
Haven't tested this on other platforms yet but now that we have a working mac os x build this error comes up when starting godot:

ERROR: create: Condition ' !create_func ' is true. returned: 0
   At: core/os/mutex.cpp:39.

Need to investigate the cause further and resolve, maybe related to visual_server_wrap_mt being removed for the time being?

Also I'm getting this error in the logs when closing godot:
ERROR: free_static: Condition ' !MemoryPoolStatic::get_singleton() ' is true.
   At: core/os/memory.cpp:58.

data.title: Fix shader tokenizer/compiler reporting wrong error location (2.2)
data.body: Raname shader tokenizer methods for clarity

data.title: Fix the order in which additional transformations are applied
data.body:
...in Matrix3 and Transform.

This is a part of the breaking changes proposed in PR #6865, solving the issue regarding the order of affine transformations described in #2565. This PR also fixed the affected code within Godot codebase. Includes improvement to documentation too.

data.title: Project Settings UI improvement idea
data.body:
Just an idea to improve the property list in Project Settings i got when writing #7435

It would be nice to separate the properties in two categories:

- Standard/Built in properties
- Custom properties

I am thinking of something similar to how Input Map actions are shown.
![project_settings](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6707330/21683399/7eb63166-d359-11e6-9486-674292daeeaa.png)

Where the "ui_accept" would just be a header, "Properties", and "ui_select" would be "Custom Properties" and the keys are how the properties should be listed.

data.title: Option to disable Tabs in TabContainer
data.body:
_This is an enhancement request to TabContainer._

It would be nice to be able to disable Tabs in a TabContainer like (or at all):

`self.set_tab_disabled(tab_idx)`

or a singal that get fired if you click on the Tab, and only the Tab but not the "area" beneath it.

In case you want to show the Player this tabs exists but you havent yet met the requierements to open it:

- you need to reach lvl 15 to choose super skills
- you need to be a guild member to access the guild options
- you cant open this tab until you finished the tutorial

To name 3 examples. I dont want to remove the tab because i want the player to know its there.
The Tab could be greyed out or something like that and clicking on it would do nothing.

data.title: Project Settings General properties position based on engine.cfg
data.body:
When a property in project settings is edited for the first time and therefor added to the engine.cfg it will be at the bottom of the property list next time project settings are loaded.

From IRC
> **Akien:** They're listed in the order the engine parses them, and engine.cfg is parsed after the ones that come directly from editor_node.cpp

Steps to reproduce:
- Go to Project Settings -> General Tab
- Choose any property in any section that haven't been edited before, and edit it
- Reload your project and the property is now at the bottom of the list

I think it would be less confusing if the properties had fixed positions, at least the standard properties.

data.title: Fixed color picker crashes the engine on Linux
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux 64 - Latest build, master branch

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The fixed color picker (from pull request #7431) crashes the engine when being used:

> ERROR: get_child: Index p_index out of size (data.children.size()).
>    At: scene/main/node.cpp:1521.

This also happens immediately when I try to open an old project. A new empty poject can be opened, but it crashes as soon as I try to use the color picker (in project settings, for example). 

I reverted that commit, recompiled and it worked again. So it is definitely caused by it.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create empty project. Open it. Go to project settings/Render. Click on the default background color to pick a new one.


**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Name given to animations when saving them.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 8.1 - 2.1.1 Stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When saving an animation to a file Godot defaults to calling it 'new_animation.tres'.
This happens even if I have already named the animation say 'Jump High' in the animation window.
Having Godot default to saving an animation with the name given to it in the animation window would be nice.

data.title: The _mouse_exit function doesn't get call in the TextureButton if the LMB is pressed
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Windows 10 - 2.1.1 stable


**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
- I made a simple scene with a Node2D as "root" and a "TextureButton" as a child.
- I added two textures for the "Pressed" and "Normal" (just black and white textures for the test) button's states
- I also added a script attached to the "root" object having the following code:
```
extends Node2D

func _on_TextureButton_mouse_enter():
	print("_on_TextureButton_mouse_enter")

func _on_TextureButton_mouse_exit():
	print("_on_TextureButton_mouse_exit")
```

**Steps to reproduce:**
1) Move the mouse cursor in the button's bounding rect (TextureButton class - I didn't test with other classes)
2) Press the LMB (**L**eft **M**ouse **B**utton)
3) Move the mouse cursor outside the button's bounding rect
4) Experience the issue: the "_mouse_exit" function doesn't get called

OBS: If you release the LMB, the function is called.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[https://github.com/radubolovan/godot_mouse_test](url)
**Edit:** looks like the link above doesn't work (I don't know why), but please copy the address and paste it in a browser.

data.title: Chinese characters with DynamicFonts rendered Super slow on Android.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
OS: Android 4.4.4 and Android 6.0.1
Godot: 2.2 and 2.1.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

Label with chinese characters are too slow to render on android.
Rendering 8 characters may need more than 1 minutes with some large ttf fonts.

This problem doesn't appears on PC(Windows and Linux are tested).
It only appears with dynamic fonts on Android.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Download the bug demo below and export to android then you will see it.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

https://github.com/Geequlim/depot/raw/master/images/godot/bug_dynamic_font.zip

data.title: Fixed inertia tensor computation and center of mass
data.body:
Issues fixed:

- To compute the distribution of mass of a rigid body the AABB was used for collision shapes for which the area (volume) is trivial to compute. Now the exact area is computed for those shapes as the AABB can have a pretty different volume if the shape is in an arbitrary orientation.

- The inertia tensor was not computed correctly because the orientation of the object w.r.t. the rigid body origin was not taken into account

- The vector of inertia only makes sense in the "Principal Axes of Inertia" frame of reference that isn't always equal to the rigid body frame of reference and which has to be computed through diagonalization of the tensor of inertia ( The Jacobi method has been implemented to diagonalize a symmetric matrix, it is the same used by Bullet ).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moment_of_inertia#Principal_axes

- The vector of inertia/inertia tensor only makes sense if computed w.r.t the rotation center i.e. the center of mass for a free rigid body, which has to be computed. The center of mass returned by the new *get_center_of_mass()* method is in global orientation with position relative to the rigid body position.

NOTE: the slider joint dosn't work but it seems not to be related to these changes as it wasn't working even without

Here is a test project with some test scenes that can be run before and after my changes to see the difference https://www.dropbox.com/sh/y44l0surabi56rb/AADpJjVHtJsv4IKwCaZnUISga?dl=0

data.title: Fix for the huge audio latency (>200 ms) for the
data.body:
PulseAudio, ALSA and RtAudio driver.

Partly fixes issue #6965. I made a post about this at there.

EDIT: I also cleaned up the code (mostly whitespace related stuff) for better readability (that is why there are so many changes in the files). And PulseAudio and ALSA do now actually use the global setting "audio/mix_rate" for the sampling rate instead of a fixed value of 44100.

(*bugsquad edit* - make it so that the issue doesn't get autoclosed if this is merged)

data.title: Better conveying that the scene has to have a root node
data.body:
As started on discussions in #7417.

Currently, it is __probably__ a bit unintuitive that scenes need to have a root node to be saved (or to be called scenes at all..). Some proposals for making it more intuitive (from the above-mentioned issue) are:
> @bojidar-bg
> Wouldn't it be better if we show a big add node button instead of the 2D/3D viewport?
Or maybe, when you click new scene, we might let you directly choose a root node, so you have nothing empty to save anyway?

> @akien-mga 
>We could refactor the option to create new scenes to be a bit like the creation of new text documents in modern word processors, showing various icons + text for the available options:
>- Create new scene with root node <Node>, with an easy to use list where you can pick any node from the typical node tree.
>  * Maybe also with 3 preconfigured choices to create a 2D (`Node2D` root), 3D (`Spatial` root) or GUI (`Control` root) scene
>- Create new scene inheriting a base scene
>- Create new scene from template (i.e. copy and rename an existing scene - potentially from outside the project folder - and open it)
>
>Not sure how useful that would be, but if done in a way that is good-looking, it could at least feel more polished and give new users something more tangible than a blank scene.

data.title: AnimationPlayer: Using the copy/paste function, changes to animations are synced between scenes till one of them is closed
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Arch Linux 64 - lastest 3.0 or 2.2 build, doesn't make a difference

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When using the copy/paste animation function in the animation player to copy an animation to an animation player in another scene, all changes made to the animation (keys, tracks, ...) are synced between the original and the pasted animation. After at least one of the scenes is closed, and reopened or you choose "make sub resources unique", they behave independent. Since they are saved in completely different scene files, they should be completely independent immediately.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Create two scenes. Create an animation player in each scene. Create an animation in one of them. Add a track and a key. Copy it and paste it into the animation player in the other scene. Make any changes to the animation. The changes are synced to the other player in the other scene. Close and reopen one of them, use "make sub resources unique" or close and reopen the whole editor. They now work independently.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Improvement to y_sort: make clear which item has to be drawn first
data.body:
when both have the same y coordinate (prevents possible flickering). 
Reapplying pull request #7241 to the 3.0 code.

data.title: Compiler complains "no symbol definition" if code "getString(R.string.var_name)" in Android module (Java singleton)
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
macOS Sierra 10.12.1, Godot 2.1 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Hi, I am not sure if it is a bug or just my misunderstanding. I write a Java module and it works fine except that it can't accept something like "getString(R.string.var_name)", where var_name is the variable put in source file: "res/values/strings.xml" as a normal Android project usually does. Can I use "getString(R.string.var_name)" in Java module (Singleton)? If yes, where should i put the var_name string in and how to add this .xml file for compiling?

**Steps to reproduce:**
Use "getString(R.string.var_name)" in Java module (Singleton) and put var_name string in "res/values/strings.xml", the compiler complains "no symbol definition of var_name"

data.title: UV modes should have a "world position mode" with a single scale factor for automatic cubic projection based on world coordinates
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
 Fedora 25 x64 - v2.1.1.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
UV modes should have a "world position mode" with a single scale factor for automatic cubic projection based on world coordinates. This is required for good brush editing, which combined with easy texture assignment ( #7418 ), easy scaling on all axes ( #7419 ) and more primitives ( #1381 ) could be an absolute game changer for being able to slap brushes of different sizes into the level quickly, then assign automatic "World UV mapping" with a basic scale factor to avoid manual UV adjustments. This is also how most oldschool BSP editors work (Quake 3, ...) which is by the way an absolutely amazing and super quick way of throwing together basic level geometry. I know this is going out of style for big budget productions where people just model everything with infinite detail in a 3d modeler, but for indie games or just quick prototyping this will always be a relevant approach to save on time.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Assign a material to a TestCube
2. Search FixedMaterial options for "Uv xForm"
3. Observe that there is no simple switch to simply use world coordinates to do an automatic cube mapping at a given scale factor

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Scale mode needs to support all axes [prototyping essential]
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
 Fedora 25 x64 - v2.1.1.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Scale mode needs to support all axes for fast prototyping. For level prototyping, multiple primitives types are absolutely required ( #1381 ) as well as fast texture assignment ( #7418 ) as well as being able to scale it on all axes separately. Otherwise, making up walls and floors is just too tedious. Unless this functionality is added, the editor will always remain more of a basic 3d model placement tool rather than something that can be actually used for making up basic levels quickly.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Press R or scale mode button
2. Observe no visible axes in the 3d view for separate dragging, and also no other obvious way to scale on just a single axis

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Dragging a texture from the "FileSystem" resources pane on the left onto a "TestCube" node in the scene explorer should create a default material and assign the texture [prototyping essential]
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Fedora 25 x64 - v2.1.1.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Dragging a texture from the "FileSystem" resources pane on the left onto a "TestCube" node in the scene explorer should create a default material and assign the texture immediately. This is required for fast prototyping, because right now it seems I am expected to first create or assign a Material manually which is way too tedious to do for every test block.

(feature request)

data.title: Empty scene should still be saveable
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Fedora 25 x64 - v2.1.1.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When starting a new project and then immediately attempting to save a new fresh 3d scene, there is some cryptic error message about a missing scene root. This is super non-intuitive and something no beginner is going to care about or even understand, so the file format should be fixed in whatever way necessary to allow saving and loading even of scenes with no objects / contents to get rid of this weird corner case.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create new project
2. Save new empty scene immediately (File -> Save)

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
